articles.headline: Trying Again for a Bill to Limit Tobacco Ads
articles.snippet: A bipartisan group of members of Congress reintroduced legislation that would allow the federal government to regulate the tobacco industry.
articles.abstract: A bipartisan group of members of Congress reintroduced legislation that would allow the federal government to regulate the tobacco industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: After being thwarted for years, a bipartisan group of members of Congress reintroduced legislation yesterday that would allow the federal government to further regulate the tobacco industry by cracking down on marketing aimed at young people and requiring that reduced-risk tobacco products back up their claims with science.

articles.headline: In Fraud Case, 7 Years in Jail for Contempt
articles.snippet: A former globe-trotting investment manager remains jailed on one of the longest-running charges of contempt.
articles.abstract: A former globe-trotting investment manager remains jailed on one of the longest-running charges of contempt.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Jan. 14, 2000, Martin A. Armstrong, a globe-trotting investment manager, was told to produce $15 million in gold and antiquities, as well as documents, in response to a civil suit by the government accusing him of securities fraud involving hundreds of millions of dollars.

articles.headline: Bear Stearns Told to Pay $160 Million to Investors
articles.snippet: The ruling could force Wall Street firms to step up oversight of some of their most lucrative clients.
articles.abstract: The ruling could force Wall Street firms to step up oversight of some of their most lucrative clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal bankruptcy judge yesterday ordered Bear Stearns to pay nearly $160 million to investors in a hedge fund for failing to properly monitor the activities of the fund before it collapsed in early 2000. The ruling could force Wall Street firms to step up oversight of some of their most lucrative clients.

articles.headline: Home Prices Fall in More Than Half of Nation’s Biggest Markets
articles.snippet: Prices for single-family homes fell in more than half of the nation’s biggest metropolitan areas in the last three months of 2006.
articles.abstract: Prices for single-family homes fell in more than half of the nation’s biggest metropolitan areas in the last three months of 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prices for single-family homes fell in more than half of the nation’s 149 biggest metropolitan areas in the last three months of 2006, according to data released yesterday by a trade group for real estate agents.

articles.headline: Stepping Lively at Credit Suisse
articles.snippet: Brady W. Dougan was named chief executive of the Credit Suisse Group, a major global bank that has never boasted an American as its sole chief executive.
articles.abstract: Brady W. Dougan was named chief executive of the Credit Suisse Group, a major global bank that has never boasted an American as its sole chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: To prepare for a charity event late last year that called for him to dance with a Broadway star, Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of Credit Suisse’s investment bank, practiced for two months.

articles.headline: Viewers Fast-Forwarding Past Ads? Not Always
articles.snippet: Owners of digital video recorders still watch on average two-thirds of commercials, a Nielsen study shows.
articles.abstract: Owners of digital video recorders still watch on average two-thirds of commercials, a Nielsen study shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: People with digital video recorders like TiVo never watch commercials, right?

articles.headline: Option Lies May Be Costly for Directors
articles.snippet: New rules in Delaware hold members of a company’s board personally liable for options shenanigans.
articles.abstract: New rules in Delaware hold members of a company’s board personally liable for options shenanigans.
articles.lead_paragraph: For companies that played games with employee stock options, the possible penalties are growing. New rulings in Delaware indicate that directors would be personally liable if options were wrongly issued.

articles.headline: Fed-Up New Orleans Residents Are Giving Up
articles.snippet: Crime, high rents and what many say is dissipating hope are driving away the best and brightest.
articles.abstract: Crime, high rents and what many say is dissipating hope are driving away the best and brightest.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 — After nearly a decade in the city of their dreams, Kasandra Larsen and her fiancé, Dylan Langlois, climbed into a rented moving truck on Marais Street last Sunday, pointed it toward New Hampshire, and said goodbye.
